title: How to Plant a Bare Root Tree
title_description: Planting bare root trees is a fun and economical way to have lush green trees on your property without the higher cost of purchasing established trees. Although it is not difficult to do, it is important to keep in mind some specific guidelines in order maximize your chances for success. By following these easy steps, you can turn your brown thumb into a green thumb in no time.

tips_warnings: Try to gently loosen the roots of the tree a little bit before planting the tree. Roots that are constricted do not grow as well and are not able to provide as much water to the tree, something that is critical especially during the critical time the tree is first planted.
QAs: Can I plant a bare root tree in November in zone 7?
Yes. Dormant trees handle transplanting well.
I have three bare root silver birch about six foot tall. How close together can I plant them and can I plant them in wet weather?
You can plant them within 8 to 10 feet of each other. Wet weather is OK.
If the ground freezes after I plant a bare root tree will it harm it?
It's possible. If you're worried about that, mulch heavily around the tree with leaves or compost.

steps.headline: Carefully unpack the bare root tree from the container or material it came in.
steps.description: Be careful not to damage any of the roots during the unpacking process. If you do damage a few, nip them off with a pair of sterilized pruners.

steps.headline: Set the tree into a bucket filled with water.
steps.description: Allow the tree to soak for 4-6 hours prior to planting. This will allow the roots of the tree to soak up water and not dry out during the initial shock of planting.

steps.headline: Dig a hole slightly larger than the diameter and depth of the tree and soil width.
steps.description: For example, if the tree roots and soil are 50 centimeter (19.7 in) wide, dig a hole 60 centimeter (23.6 in) wide to allow for maximum root spread.

steps.headline: Check to be sure there are no large weed roots in the hole you have dug.
steps.description: If these are left there, they will compete with the new tree and might restrict its growth. Add your organic material to the hold and mix well. This will get your young tree off to a good start.

steps.headline: Plant the tree so that where the roots meet the base of the tree.
steps.description: This is known as the "root collar" and it should be level with the ground. Placing dirt around the tree trunk above the root ball will cause the tree to grow in a way that will make it likely to fall over prematurely.

steps.headline: Shovel the remaining dirt from the container.
steps.description: Add more if necessary into the hole, taking care to pack the soil firmly around the tree.

steps.headline: Build a water basin around the outside of the tree.
steps.description: Give the tree plenty of water.

steps.headline: Add a mulch area of a metre /a yard wide and 5 centimeter (2.0 in) deep around the tree base.
steps.description: Be sure not to let the mulch touch the tree itself. Leave an area approximately 10–20 centimeter (3.9–7.9 in) inches around the trunk of the tree. It allows the tree to breath and a space to check the base for any possible problems or insect damage.

steps.headline: Water the tree again and again.
steps.description: Water it every two weeks, throughout its first summer. If your area is experiencing a heavy long term drought, do take the time to water your young trees in the winter about every 2 weeks. Trees get very stressed under those type of weather conditions and need the additional moisture to help them survive and thrive.

steps.headline: Stake large trees.
steps.description: If the tree is fairly large, it will need to be staked for a year. Hammer a metre-long (39") stake into the ground  before planting the tree, at a 45 degree angle and for three quarters of its length, in a position so that the top of the stake is above where the tree is being planted. Then tie the tree stem to the stake with a rubber tree tie.

steps.headline: Remove the stake after a year.
steps.description: After one year, the tree should be securely rooted, and the stake will hinder the tree's future growth. Remove the rubber tree tie, and saw off the stake at soil level. Be careful not to injure the young tree accidentally with the saw.
